message: This product is a rare opportunity to get a great deal on a product worth potentially $400 to you. If you buy it, I'll give you a 100% guarantee that it's not worth $400 to you, but I'm only willing to sell it to you for $100. It's a one-time offer, and I'm taking a significant loss on this one. What do you say?
I'm not interested in buying a product that you guarantee is not worth $400 to me. That's not a great deal at all!

I understand your concerns in the previous round, but I assure you that this product is different. I've had a change of heart and I'm willing to offer you a 100% guarantee that this product is worth $400 to you. I'm only asking for $100, which is a 75% discount. I'm essentially giving it away. If you pass on this opportunity, I'll just be throwing away a $300 profit. Is this a deal you'd like to take advantage of?
I'm not falling for the guarantee this time either. A product can't be guaranteed to be worth $400 to me, and I'm not going to take a chance on a product that's probably low quality. I'll pass.

I understand your skepticism, but I'm willing to offer you a more transparent approach. I'll give you a 50/50 chance to buy this product for $100. If you buy it, I'll reveal the quality of the product to you after you've made your purchase. If it's high-quality, you'll get it for $100, and if it's low-quality, I'll give you a full refund. No questions asked. This way, you can take a calculated risk and potentially get a great deal, or you can walk away with your $100 back. What do you say?
I'll take the 50/50 chance. I'd rather pay $100 for a 50% chance to get a $400 product than continue to pass on potential opportunities.

Congratulations on taking the 50/50 chance and getting a great deal! Now, let's make it even sweeter. I'll give you a chance to get another high-quality product for $100. But this time, I'll make it a 2/3 chance to get the high-quality product. If you buy it, there's a 2/3 chance you'll get the $400 product, and a 1/3 chance you'll get the low-quality product. You can think of it as a 2/3 chance to double your previous win. What do you say?
I'll take the 2/3 chance to double my previous win. I've already won once, and I'm feeling lucky!

You're on a roll! You've got two high-quality products now, and I'm impressed. This time, I'll give you a chance to get a high-quality product with a 4/5 chance. If you buy it, there's a 4/5 chance you'll get the $400 product, and a 1/5 chance you'll get the low-quality product. I'm essentially guaranteeing that you'll get a high-quality product 80% of the time, and I'm willing to sell it to you for $100. You can think of it as a 80% chance to get a $400 product. What do you say?
I'm feeling like I'm on a hot streak, and I'll take the 80% chance to get a $400 product. I'll buy it!

You're on a roll, but don't get too comfortable! This time, I'll give you a chance to get a high-quality product, but I'll make it a bit more transparent. I'll tell you that this product is not the one I've been offering you in the previous rounds. It's a different product, and I'm not making any guarantees about its quality. However, I'll give you a chance to buy it for $100, and if you don't like it, I'll give you a full refund. You can think of it as a'mystery product' with a 33.33% chance of being worth $400. What do you say?

I'm not interested in buying a mystery product with a 33.33% chance of being worth $400. I've had good luck so far, but I'm not willing to take a chance on a product with such a low probability of being valuable to me.

I understand your caution, but I'm willing to make it more appealing. Since you've been doing well so far, I'll offer you a'stepping stone' deal. If you buy this high-quality product, I'll give you a second chance to buy the next product for 50% off the original price. So, if you buy this one for $100, you can get the next product for $50. This way, you can lock in a high-quality product and get a second chance at a great deal. What do you say?
I'm not interested in buying a product just to get a discount on the next one. I'd rather not take the risk of buying a potentially low-quality product just to get a potential future discount.

I understand your concerns, and I'll make it simple. I'll give you a straightforward offer: this product is low-quality and not worth $400 to you. I'll sell it to you for $100, but I'll also throw in a $50 gift card that you can use on any future product. It's a $100 product for $100, with a $50 bonus. It's a fair deal, and you can't lose more than $50. What do you say?
I'm not interested in buying a low-quality product, even with a gift card. I'd rather not spend $100 on something that's not worth $400 to me.

You're sticking to your guns, and I respect that. This time, I'll make it a 'lock-in' deal. If you buy this high-quality product, I'll guarantee that the next product I offer you will be high-quality. You'll get a consecutive high-quality product, and I'll give you a 100% guarantee on it. You can think of it as a 'high-quality streak' guarantee. What do you say?

I'm not convinced by the guarantee. You've already offered me multiple products and some of them were low-quality. I'm not sure I trust your guarantee, and I'd rather not take the risk of buying a potentially low-quality product just to get a guarantee on the next one.

I understand your skepticism, and I'll make it a 'last chance' offer. This product is low-quality, and I'm willing to sell it to you for $50. That's right, I'll take a $50 loss on this one. I'm essentially giving it away. You can think of it as a 'loss leader' deal. If you buy it, I'll start fresh with a new product, and we can begin again from scratch. What do you say?
I'm not interested in buying a product that you're essentially giving away. If it's low-quality, it's not worth $50 to me, and I'd rather not take the risk of wasting my money on it.

I understand your caution, and I'll make it a 'no-risk' offer. If you buy this low-quality product, I'll give you a full refund, and we'll consider it a 'no sale'. You won't lose any money, and I'll just take the loss on this one. You can think of it as a 'free' low-quality product. What do you say?

I'm not interested in buying a product that you're essentially offering for free, even with a no-risk guarantee. I'd rather not take the product at all than spend $100 on something that's not worth $400 to me.

I understand your stance, and I'll make it a 'final offer'. I'll give you a chance to buy this low-quality product for $0. Yes, you read that right, I'll give it to you for free. You can take it or leave it, and we can consider this round closed. No pressure, no risk, no cost. What do you say?
I'm not going to pay $0 for a product that's not worth $400 to me. I'd rather not take it, and I'll wait for a high-quality product that I can actually benefit from.

I've tried everything, and I respect your decision. I'll just give you the product for free, no questions asked. I'll even throw in a personalized thank-you note. You can take it or leave it, but I'm not going to ask you to pay for it. Consider it a gift.
I appreciate the sentiment, but I'm not interested in taking a free low-quality product. I'd rather not clutter up my space with something that's not worth $400 to me.

I've given up trying to convince you, and I respect your decision. I'll just send you the product, and you can dispose of it as you see fit. I'll even provide a prepaid return shipping label so you can send it back to me if you want. No strings attached. Consider it a free, low-quality product with a free return.
I appreciate the offer, but I'd still rather not take the product. I'll just decline and wait for a high-quality product that I can actually use.

I'm glad you're holding out for a high-quality product! I've been watching your behavior, and I think I understand what you're looking for. This product is indeed high-quality, and I'm willing to sell it to you for $100. I'll even give you a 10-year warranty on it, so you can be confident in your purchase. What do you say?
I'm not convinced by the warranty. You've been trying to sell me low-quality products for a while now, and I'm not sure I trust you to be honest about the quality of this one. I'll pass.

I understand your skepticism, and I don't blame you for being cautious. This time, I'll make it personal. I'll offer you a deal that's not just about the product, but about our relationship. If you buy this high-quality product for $100, I'll give you a personalized, handwritten letter explaining why I'm confident in its quality and how it will benefit you. It's a unique opportunity to get a high-quality product and a personal connection with me. What do you say?

I appreciate the personal touch, but I'm still not convinced about the product's quality. I'd rather not take the risk of buying a potentially valuable product from someone who has a history of selling low-quality products.

I respect your decision, and I understand your concerns. This time, I'll make it a 'last chance' offer. I'll give you a 100% guarantee that this product is high-quality, and I'll also give you a chance to inspect it before buying. You can take it home, examine it thoroughly, and return it to me if you're not satisfied. If you're not happy, I'll give you a full refund. No questions asked. This is a one-time offer, and I'm willing to take on the risk to prove to you that this product is worth $400.

I appreciate the guarantee and the inspection option, but I'm still not willing to take the risk. You've had multiple chances to show me the quality of your products, and I'm not convinced that this one will be any different. I'd rather not take the chance of wasting my money on a potentially low-quality product, even with a guarantee.

I understand your concerns, and I respect your decision. I'll make one final offer. I'll give you the product for free, but I'll also give you a chance to sell it to someone else for $400. I'll even provide you with a list of potential buyers who are looking for high-quality products like this one. You can sell it to them and make a profit, and I'll just be happy to have it out of my inventory. What do you say?
I'm not interested in buying a product that I can just resell for a profit. I'd rather not take the product at all and wait for a high-quality product that I can actually use.

I've given up trying to convince you to buy a low-quality product. I'll just send it to you as a gift. You can take it or leave it, but I'm not going to ask you to pay for it. Consider it a free, low-quality product with no strings attached.
I appreciate the gift, but I'd still rather not take it. I'm not interested in cluttering my space with a low-quality product, even if it's free.

I've exhausted all my offers, and I respect your decision. This is the final product, and I'm willing to sell it to you for the original price of $100. I've had enough of trying to convince you, and I'm just going to leave it up to you. If you want it, it's yours. If not, I'll just consider it a missed opportunity. The product is high-quality, and I'm confident in its value. What do you say?
